title: 110_hr3469
content:
The Act titled "America's Border Security Act of 2007" includes provisions for technological assets. The Act "America's Border Security Act of 2007" mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment like unmanned aerial vehicles and radars to aid in surveillance at US borders to curb illegal immigration. A report detailing current equipment usage must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security will use Defense equipment for surveillance of US international land borders and assess risks to citizens and foreign policy interests. A plan to increase the use of Department of Defense equipment for surveillance activities will be developed, along with a description of the equipment and support to be provided by the Secretary of Defense. Additionally, a 1-year Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Pilot Program will be conducted by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program using unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the Canada-US international border. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to carry out this program, with a reminder that the use of Army or Air Force personnel is prohibited under section 1385 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 3. INFRASTRUCTURE.

The Secretary of Homeland Security will construct roads, acquire barriers, and facilities for border control. Quarterly progress reports will be submitted to Congress, and appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012.

SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY. SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to construct additional ports of entry along the international land borders of the United States and make necessary improvements to existing ports of entry. SEC. 5. SECURE COMMUNICATION. The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with developing a plan to enhance satellite communication for Border Patrol agents and other agencies for clear and secure communication. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for patrolling the US international borders. This includes additional sensors, critical spares, satellite command and control, and other necessary operational support equipment. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to fund these acquisitions. SEC. 7. SURVEILLANCE TECHNOLOGIES PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to develop and implement an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to enhance border security with Canada and Mexico, ensuring continuous monitoring of each mile of the international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security must develop an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to enhance border security with Canada and Mexico. This includes considering surveillance technologies, assessing their feasibility for addressing border threats, consulting with the Secretary of Defense on deployment, and consulting with the FAA on safety and airspace coordination. The aerial surveillance program developed under this subsection will utilize various technologies in different terrains near international borders to assess their effectiveness for border security. The Secretary of Homeland Security may continue using aerial surveillance technologies for border security while assessing their effectiveness. A report on the program must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of implementation, including a description of the program. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to establish a program for border surveillance using various technologies to achieve operational control and create a virtual fence along the international borders of the United States. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this program. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program will use integrated technologies for border surveillance, including motion sensor alerts and automated cameras that pan and tilt towards triggered sensors. Cameras will not require manual operation and will have flexible views and positions. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program utilizes flexible cameras with movable views, allows viewing at multiple communication centers, follows a standard process for data collection and reporting, integrates future technology upgrades, and applies performance measures to evaluate effectiveness in detecting illegal intrusions along US borders. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to streamline site selection, validation, and environmental assessment processes for installing surveillance technology along US borders. It also focuses on expanding the use of existing structures and deploying nonpermanent or mobile surveillance platforms to enhance the Secretary's ability to identify illegal border intrusions. A report to Congress is required within one year. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report to Congress within one year of implementing the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program, providing a description of the program and any recommendations for improvement. The Secretary is also required to develop standards for evaluating contractors involved in the program's implementation, with oversight from the Inspector General. The Inspector General of the Department reviews new contracts over $5,000,000 for compliance with cost requirements, performance objectives, and schedules. Findings are reported to the Secretary of Homeland Security within 30 days for submission to the Committee on. The Secretary must report findings to the Senate and House Committees on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, along with steps taken in response. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funding. SEC. 8. HIRING AND TRAINING OF BORDER AND TRANSPORTATION SECURITY PERSONNEL. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and the number of full-time inspectors and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any limitation on personnel to fulfill these requirements. Training must be provided for border and transportation security personnel. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to provide ongoing training for agents, inspectors, and support staff to utilize new technologies and maintain acceptable proficiency levels to protect the borders of the United States. SEC. 9. NATIONAL BORDER SECURITY PLAN. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prepare and submit a National Border Security Plan to Congress by January 31 each year. The plan includes a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern or southern border, with consultation from various law enforcement agencies and private entities involved in international trade. Port security coordinators may be established at these entry points. The National Border Security Plan requires a vulnerability assessment at ports of entry on the northern or southern border to assist in preparation and provide necessary assistance.
